epidemiology: Occurs in ~13 million people/year globally. Common in hospitalized and critically ill patients. Associated with high mortality.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Supportive care → Initiate dialysis if refractory or severe

epidemiology: Affects ~10% of the global population. Risk increases with age, diabetes, and hypertension.
treatment_protocol: Stage CKD → Slow progression → Plan for RRT if advanced

epidemiology: Characterized by proteinuria >3.5g/day. More common in children (minimal change disease) and adults (FSGS, membranous GN).

definitive: Steroids or immunosuppressants depending on cause

treatment_protocol: Control symptoms → Identify cause → Immunotherapy if needed

epidemiology: Often caused by post-infectious glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis. Common in children and young adults.
treatment_protocol: Treat underlying cause → Control BP → Immunotherapy if indicated

epidemiology: Affects 1 in 400–1000 people. Autosomal dominant form accounts for >90% cases. Progressive renal enlargement and failure.

definitive: Dialysis or kidney transplant if ESRD

treatment_protocol: Monitor function → Treat complications → Transplant in ESRD

epidemiology: Rare disorder of renal tubules resulting in normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Types 1 (distal), 2 (proximal), 4 (hyperkalemic).
treatment_protocol: Classify type → Correct acid-base → Monitor electrolytes

epidemiology: Most common glomerulonephritis worldwide. Peaks in 2nd-3rd decade of life. Higher prevalence in Asia.

definitive: Steroids in select patients with proteinuria

treatment_protocol: Supportive → Consider steroids if proteinuria persists

epidemiology: Rare autoimmune disease with anti-GBM antibodies. Bimodal age distribution (20–30 and 60–70 years).
treatment_protocol: Immunosuppression + plasmapheresis → Monitor renal and pulmonary function

epidemiology: X-linked hereditary nephritis. Associated with sensorineural hearing loss and ocular abnormalities. Presents in childhood.
risk_factors: Family history of renal disease or hearing loss
treatment_protocol: Supportive until ESRD → Renal replacement therapy

epidemiology: Affects up to 60% of patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). More common in females and certain ethnic groups (e.g., African descent).
treatment_protocol: Induction → Maintenance therapy based on biopsy class

epidemiology: Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white adults. Primary (idiopathic) or secondary to malignancy, infection, drugs, or autoimmune disease.
treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Immunosuppression for high-risk patients

epidemiology: Common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, particularly in African descent. Can be primary or secondary to obesity, HIV, or reflux nephropathy.

definitive: Steroids or calcineurin inhibitors for primary FSGS

treatment_protocol: Biopsy-confirmed → Immunosuppression if primary → Treat cause if secondary

epidemiology: Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Often idiopathic but may follow infection or drug use (NSAIDs).
treatment_protocol: Empiric steroids → Renal biopsy if no remission

epidemiology: Leading cause of ESRD globally. Develops in ~20–40% of diabetic patients. More common in Type 1 with >10 years of disease.
treatment_protocol: Early detection → BP and glucose control → Prepare for RRT in advanced stages

epidemiology: Chronic kidney damage due to long-standing hypertension. Common in older adults and African Americans.

supportive: Strict BP control with ACE inhibitors

treatment_protocol: Early diagnosis → Aggressive BP management

epidemiology: Can be AL (plasma cell dyscrasia) or AA (chronic inflammation). Renal involvement leads to nephrotic syndrome and progressive CKD.

important: Renal biopsy with Congo red staining

treatment_protocol: Identify type → Systemic therapy for AL → Supportive renal care

epidemiology: Occurs in ~1-5% of hypertensive patients. Atherosclerosis is the most common cause in older adults; fibromuscular dysplasia in younger women.

emergency_markers: Acute kidney injury after ACE inhibitor

definitive: Angioplasty with or without stenting (especially for FMD)

treatment_protocol: Identify etiology → Optimize BP → Revascularization if indicated

epidemiology: Can affect all ages; caused by stones, tumors, strictures, or BPH. Leads to hydronephrosis and kidney dysfunction if untreated.

emergency_markers: Acute kidney injury with bilateral obstruction

treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Decompress → Address underlying etiology

epidemiology: Most common inherited kidney disorder. Autosomal dominant form presents in adulthood and affects 1 in 1000 people.
treatment_protocol: Monitor → Control complications → Renal replacement in ESRD

epidemiology: Rare; occurs due to tubular defects in acid handling. Four types, with types I and IV most clinically relevant.
treatment_protocol: Correct acidosis → Monitor electrolytes → Treat cause

epidemiology: Chronic renal disease due to long-term use of analgesics (especially phenacetin, NSAIDs). Often affects middle-aged women.

definitive: Renal replacement therapy in advanced stages

treatment_protocol: Stop nephrotoxic agents → Supportive renal care

epidemiology: Affects up to 60% of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients. More common and severe in African Americans and Hispanics.
treatment_protocol: Classify via biopsy → Immunosuppressive therapy → Monitor remission

epidemiology: Follows group A streptococcal infections, especially in children. Occurs 1-3 weeks after pharyngitis or impetigo.

definitive: Supportive care; antibiotics for active strep infection

treatment_protocol: Confirm strep etiology → Symptomatic treatment → Monitor renal function

epidemiology: Common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Can be idiopathic or secondary to infections, malignancy, drugs.
treatment_protocol: Risk stratification → Conservative vs. immunosuppressive therapy

epidemiology: Classic (typical) HUS follows shiga toxin-producing E. coli infection in children. Atypical HUS is complement-mediated and rarer.
treatment_protocol: Supportive in typical HUS → Consider eculizumab in atypical

epidemiology: IgA vasculitis is the most common vasculitis in children. Renal involvement occurs in up to 50%, presenting with IgA nephropathy.

definitive: Steroids for significant proteinuria or worsening renal function

treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Biopsy in severe cases → Consider steroids

epidemiology: Leading cause of ESRD worldwide. Affects ~20–40% of patients with diabetes mellitus.
treatment_protocol: Screen annually → Control risk factors → Manage CKD progression

epidemiology: AL and AA amyloidosis can affect kidneys. Renal involvement is common in systemic amyloidosis. More common in older adults.

important: Renal biopsy with Congo red stain

definitive: Treat underlying inflammation in AA type

treatment_protocol: Confirm amyloid type → Supportive and disease-specific therapy

epidemiology: More common in children with metabolic disorders and adults with hyperparathyroidism. Prevalence ~7% in radiologic series.
treatment_protocol: Identify metabolic cause → Control calcium/phosphate → Monitor renal function

epidemiology: Occurs due to chronic hypoperfusion from renal artery stenosis or systemic atherosclerosis. Common in elderly with cardiovascular disease.

emergency_markers: Sudden BP rise with renal dysfunction

treatment_protocol: Assess perfusion → Optimize medical therapy → Revascularize if needed

epidemiology: Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Can also occur in adults (~10–15% of cases).
treatment_protocol: Empirical steroids in children → Biopsy in adults → Treat & monitor relapse

epidemiology: A leading cause of ESRD in developing countries. Can evolve from various glomerular diseases.
treatment_protocol: Manage underlying cause → Delay progression → Prepare for RRT in ESRD

epidemiology: A common cause of postrenal AKI, especially in elderly males with BPH or malignancy.
treatment_protocol: Identify obstruction → Relieve promptly → Monitor renal recovery

epidemiology: Common in African descent. A major cause of ESRD in hypertensive patients, especially with poorly controlled BP.
treatment_protocol: Aggressive BP control → Slow progression → Evaluate for ESRD care

epidemiology: Syndromic diagnosis; includes proteinuria >3.5g/day, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. Can result from various glomerulopathies.
treatment_protocol: Confirm syndrome → Investigate cause → Treat underlying disease

epidemiology: Accounts for ~10–15% of AKI cases. Caused by drugs, infections, or autoimmune diseases.

definitive: Steroids for severe or persistent cases

treatment_protocol: Identify trigger → Supportive care → Steroids if no recovery

epidemiology: Atherosclerosis is the most common cause in adults; fibromuscular dysplasia in younger females. Present in ~1–5% of hypertensive patients.

emergency_markers: Sudden rise in creatinine with ACEI

treatment_protocol: Diagnose with imaging → Optimize BP & lipids → Revascularize if needed

epidemiology: Uncommon but important cause of non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. Often diagnosed in childhood or secondary to autoimmune disorders.
treatment_protocol: Identify type → Correct acidosis/electrolytes → Monitor long-term bone/kidney health

epidemiology: Accounts for 90–95% of all kidney cancers. Most common in men aged 50–70. Associated with smoking and obesity.
treatment_protocol: Stage tumor → Surgery if resectable → Systemic therapy if advanced

epidemiology: Common in nephrotic syndrome and hypercoagulable states. More frequent in adults with membranous nephropathy.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Anticoagulate → Monitor for complications

epidemiology: Genetic disorder affecting type IV collagen. X-linked dominant most common. Leads to progressive renal failure, hearing loss, and ocular changes.

emergency_markers: Rapid deterioration of renal function in adolescence

treatment_protocol: Early detection → Supportive care → Transplantation if ESRD

epidemiology: Rare X-linked lysosomal storage disorder due to alpha-galactosidase A deficiency. Affects kidneys, heart, and nervous system.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with genetic/enzyme test → Start enzyme replacement → Monitor progression

epidemiology: Rare immune complex-mediated GN. Can be idiopathic or secondary to infections, autoimmune disease, or monoclonal gammopathy.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose via biopsy → Rule out secondary causes → Immunotherapy as indicated

epidemiology: Autosomal recessive disorder causing impaired renal reabsorption of cystine, leading to recurrent kidney stones.

emergency_markers: Stone obstruction with infection or AKI

treatment_protocol: Increase fluid intake → Alkalinize urine → Add chelators for recurrent stones

epidemiology: Affects ~50% of SLE patients. More common in women and people of African/Asian descent. Major cause of morbidity.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with biopsy → Classify → Immunotherapy + maintenance

epidemiology: A leading cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Can be primary or secondary to obesity, infections, or drugs.
treatment_protocol: Biopsy diagnosis → Steroid trial → Add CNIs if resistant

epidemiology: Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Can occur in adults. Often follows viral infections or allergic reactions.
treatment_protocol: Start steroids → Monitor remission → Taper as appropriate

epidemiology: Associated with systemic amyloidosis (AL, AA). Often presents with nephrotic-range proteinuria and progressive renal dysfunction.

important: Renal biopsy with Congo red staining

treatment_protocol: Confirm amyloid type → Treat underlying disorder → Support renal function

epidemiology: Most common cause of CKD and ESRD worldwide. Seen in ~30–40% of diabetic patients.

definitive: No cure; slow progression with tight metabolic control

treatment_protocol: Early detection → Optimize BP/glucose → Monitor renal progression

epidemiology: Common cause of CKD in hypertensive patients, especially in Black populations. Associated with long-standing uncontrolled hypertension.
treatment_protocol: Control BP <130/80 → Monitor renal function → Manage CV risk factors

epidemiology: Accounts for 20% of community and hospital-acquired AKI. Caused by NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, contrast agents, etc.
treatment_protocol: Identify & discontinue drug → Supportive care → Monitor for recovery

epidemiology: AIN accounts for 10-15% of intrinsic AKI in hospitalized patients. Often drug-induced.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Discontinue agent → Supportive care ± steroids

epidemiology: Chronic kidney disease caused by prolonged use of analgesics, especially combination products. More common in middle-aged women.
risk_factors: Chronic NSAID or combination analgesic use
treatment_protocol: Discontinue causative drug → Monitor renal function → Treat sequelae

epidemiology: Atherosclerotic RAS accounts for >90% of cases. Fibromuscular dysplasia more common in young women.

emergency_markers: Acute rise in creatinine after ACEI

treatment_protocol: Imaging confirmation → Medical management → Revascularization if indicated

epidemiology: Includes HUS, TTP, and secondary causes (e.g., malignancy, pregnancy, drugs). Characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Plasma exchange or eculizumab → Monitor closely

epidemiology: Progressive loss of renal function due to reduced blood flow, usually from bilateral renal artery stenosis.
treatment_protocol: Confirm ischemia → Conservative treatment → Consider angioplasty

epidemiology: Rare but serious cause of glomerulonephritis, associated with chronic infections (e.g., HCV), autoimmune disease, and monoclonal gammopathy.

definitive: Treat underlying cause (e.g., HCV, immune suppression)

treatment_protocol: Evaluate cause → Control BP/proteinuria → Immunotherapy if needed

epidemiology: Can occur in nephrotic syndrome, malignancy, dehydration (infants). More common in hypercoagulable states.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with imaging → Start anticoagulation → Long-term management

epidemiology: Common hereditary cause of CKD; affects ~1 in 500 to 1,000 people. Progressive development of renal cysts.

emergency_markers: Severe headache with family history of aneurysms

definitive: Tolvaptan to slow progression in select patients

treatment_protocol: Monitor renal function → Screen family → Manage hypertension and complications

epidemiology: Chronic tubulointerstitial injury from long-term NSAIDs, lithium, toxins, or systemic disorders (e.g., Sjogren’s).
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Remove offending agent → Monitor for progression

epidemiology: Group of disorders causing non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. Classified as Type 1 (distal), Type 2 (proximal), or Type 4 (hypoaldosteronism).
treatment_protocol: Classify type → Electrolyte correction → Long-term management

epidemiology: Rare cause of AKI; accounts for <2% of all AKI. Seen in obstetric complications, sepsis, and snake bites.

emergency_markers: Sudden oliguria/anuria after shock or trauma

definitive: No specific cure; supportive care only

treatment_protocol: Identify precipitant → Supportive care → Long-term renal follow-up

epidemiology: Occurs in ~40% of multiple myeloma patients. Common cause of AKI in myeloma.
treatment_protocol: Hydrate → Confirm myeloma → Treat underlying disease

epidemiology: Occurs in up to 60% of patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), especially women of childbearing age.
treatment_protocol: Classify by biopsy → Start induction + maintenance therapy → Monitor renal function

epidemiology: Renal involvement common in systemic amyloidosis (AL or AA type). AL amyloidosis often from plasma cell dyscrasias.

important: Renal biopsy with Congo red stain

definitive: Chemotherapy or anti-inflammatory treatment depending on type

treatment_protocol: Confirm amyloidosis → Classify type → Treat underlying disorder

epidemiology: Occurs in tumor lysis syndrome or in chronic hyperuricemia. Common in hematologic malignancies after chemotherapy.

emergency_markers: Rapidly rising creatinine in TLS setting

treatment_protocol: Prophylaxis in high-risk patients → Monitor uric acid → Treat hyperuricemia

epidemiology: A rare autosomal recessive renal tubular disorder. Onset often in infancy or childhood.
risk_factors: Genetic mutations affecting ion channels (e.g., SLC12A1, KCNJ1)

definitive: No cure; lifelong electrolyte and volume management

treatment_protocol: Diagnose early → Manage electrolytes → Monitor growth and development

epidemiology: Inherited autosomal recessive disorder affecting NaCl transport in distal tubule. Often asymptomatic until adolescence/adulthood.
treatment_protocol: Maintain electrolytes → Symptomatic relief → Long-term follow-up

epidemiology: Genetic disorder affecting type IV collagen. X-linked is most common. Leads to progressive renal failure, hearing loss, and ocular defects.
risk_factors: Family history of hematuria or ESRD
treatment_protocol: Screen early → Monitor renal function → Manage proteinuria → Transplant if needed

epidemiology: X-linked lysosomal storage disease. Renal involvement begins in adolescence. Causes progressive CKD.

emergency_markers: Rapid renal decline in young male with pain

treatment_protocol: Diagnose early → Start ERT → Monitor renal and cardiac function

epidemiology: Calcium deposition in renal parenchyma. Associated with hyperparathyroidism, distal RTA, and hypervitaminosis D.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Control calcium-phosphate metabolism → Follow up imaging
